description: Professor Kisaragi created the android Cutey Honey. He made her with the 'Fixed System of Air Elements' that creates anything out of thin air. Panther Claw, an evil organization, desires this device and will stop at nothing! Not even Professor Kisaragi who is tragically killed. Honey swears revenge and will stop at nothing to destroy the Panther Claw.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Villainess
tags.description: Centers around or prominently features a villainous noble lady.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Slapstick
tags.description: Prominently features comedy based on deliberately clumsy actions or embarrassing events.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Boarding School
tags.description: Features characters attending a boarding school.

tags.name: Superhero
tags.description: Prominently features super-powered humans who aim to serve the greater good.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Gambling
tags.description: Centers around the act of gambling.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Motorcycles
tags.description: Prominently features the use of motorcycles.

tags.name: Ninja
tags.description: Prominently features Japanese warriors traditionally trained in espionage, sabotage and assasination.

tags.name: Mermaid

tags.name: Cowboys
tags.description: Features Western or Western-inspired cowboys.

title.native: 新・キューティーハニー

name.native: タランチュラパンサー

node.description:
Kiyoshi Nagai, better known by the pen name Gou Nagai, is a Japanese manga artist and a prolific author of science fiction, fantasy, horror and erotica. He made his professional debut in 1967 with Meakashi Polikichi, but is best known for creating popular 1970s manga and anime series such as [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/manga/86168/Cutey-Honey/), [Devilman](https://anilist.co/manga/31474/Devilman/) and [Mazinger Z](https://anilist.co/manga/38773/Mazinger-Z/). He is credited with creating the super robot genre and for designing the first mecha robots piloted by a user from within a cockpit with Mazinger Z, and for pioneering the magical girl genre with Cutie Honey, the post-apocalyptic genre with [Violence Jack](https://anilist.co/manga/31442/Violence-Jack/), and the ecchi genre with [Harenchi Gakuen](https://anilist.co/manga/42808/Harenchi-Gakuen/). 

In 2005, he became a Character Design professor at the Osaka University of Arts. He has been a member of the Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize's nominating committee since 2009.

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~
He was a music composer for anime, drama and jidaigeki from Tokyo, Japan. He passed away from renal failure.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/伊藤アキラ)

He graduated from the Tokyo University of Education. He did a wide range of lyrics for kayoukyoku, anime, novelty and advertisement, more than 1000 songs, giving him the reputation of a "hardcore lyricist" in japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/mtsujiji) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/辻真先) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masaki_Tsuji)

Tsuji was most active in the business from the '60s through the '80s, and worked as a screenwriter on many popular anime television series for [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), and [Tokyo Movie Shinsha](https://anilist.co/studio/65/). He is well known for his association with the animated adaptations of the works of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/) and [Go Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/). In April 2007, Tsuji headed Japan's first international anime research lab as part of Digital Hollywood University. In 2007, he was given a lifetime achievement award at the 11th Japan Media Arts Festival. In 2008, he won a Special Award in the 13th Animation Kobe for his writing work.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森下孝三)

The managing director of [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on various works in '70s and '80s.

Passed away on due to a cancerous tumor on his neck on March 24, 2000.

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

__Birth Place:__ Shimane Prefecture, Japan

Okasako Nobuhiro is an animator, character designer and director. 

He entered Toei Douga in 1958 and has since gone through Mushi Production, Nippon Housou Douga (日本放送動画) and Tsuchida Production. In 1987 he established the animation studio Studio Victory and became its representative.
